yeah, I spelt it right: evolism. a term I just invented (hopefully) and which I will define for the purpose of this thread. I will put working definitions for creation and christianity here too
 
 Evolism - the belief that the universe and life in it originated from "scientific" processes. ie, the universe began at the Big Bang; life began in a primordal pool of organic chemicals; man evolved from "lesser" primates, which evolved from prehistoric mammals over millions of years
 
 Creationism - (not a newly invented term) the belief that God created the world and all life forms in 6 days as described in Genesis 1 & 2
 
 Christianity - the belief that Jesus Christ, the Son of God (who is also God Himself) has made a way for man to be reconciled to God by dying for the sins of man, and the acceptance that Jesus Himself is that very way of reconciliation/salvation from unforgiveness/damnation
 
 Bible - a composite of books, supposedly inspired by God, and supposedly 100% true, where the stories of creation and Jesus' ministry both come from
 
 
 OK, I really started this thread in religion forum, but I'll restart it here since I didnt start it as I should have.
 
 So, the question: is it possible to accept evolism as true and yet subscribe to christianity? can you reject creationism and adhere to christianity while holding the belief that the Bible is God's word and 100% true? is evolism incompatible with the bible?

 Evolution (from Talk.Origins) - a process that results in heritable changes in a population spread over many generations; any change in the frequency of alleles within a gene pool from one generation to the next
 
 Evolution, as far as I see has no conflict with any belief system. but this wasnt the original question

I'll keep this brief, since we have discussed it in the 'Science vs Religion???' post. But I see no conflicts between 'Evolism' and 'Christianity' as you define them. Whether or not there is a God as perceived by Christianity does not negate the possibility that there was a Big Bang and that the universe developed completely according to observable, natural laws and scientific processes. 
 
 IF, however, you define Evolism with the additional statement of 'all of this happened spontaneously out of nothingness without being set in motion by some force outside of the universe.' Then there would be a conflict between the two belief systems. Because Christianity holds that there is a 'force' outside of the physical realm of the universe.

lurch

But you did include evolution in your definition of evolism. You said, "man evolved from "lesser" primates, which evolved from prehistoric mammals over millions of years." That's evolution, isn't it?
 
 But there are three (at least) different meanings for the word "evolution" as used by evolutionary scientists. Creationists have a different meaning or meanings.
 
 First, there is the definition of evolution. That is what you gave. It is not a statement of theory or an explanation of observations. It is a statement of what observable events are to be considered evolutionary. The definition you got from T.O. is good. Here's what I learned it was many years ago. Evolution is a change in the frequency in alleles in a population over time. What I said and what T.O. said are the same - we just used different words.
 
 Since we are into defining things I'll define my terms too. I won't presume how much knowlege of biology anyone has although I presume that Mr. Jack is well informed and you seem to have done some reading at T.O. But there might be others.
 
 an allele is one of two or more alternate forms of a gene. Eye color is an example of alleles. Blood types is another. There are between 30 to 40 thousand genes in the human genome. This was a great surprise to geneticists. They had estimated many more. There are an average of 14 alleles for every gene - some good, some bad, and some don't matter much.
 
 By frequency I mean relative proportion. It can be stated as a percentage of the population that has that allele. Everyone has two alleles for any given gene - they may be the same or they may be different.
 
 Notice that it is a population that evolves, not individuals. A population is a group of interbreeding organisms.
 
 And finally, the time I speak of involves reproduction. As I said, individuals don't evolve. There must be reproduction and the genes must be passed on the the next generation.
 
 Second, when events that fit the above definition are observed, we say that we have observed evolution. The change in color from light to dark and back again of the peppered moth observed in England over the last 150 years is evolution. Notice that there is no goal, no sense of progress, no getting better and better.
 
 Finally, there are the explanations for why evolution happens - the theories and hypotheses. There are lots of theories and hypotheses of evolution. The major theories have been around for so long and have been to thoroughly tested that they aren't questioned any more.
 
 And I don't believe any of it.
unkerpaulie

thank you lurch for your useful definitions. its nice to read a post from you without feeling intimidated by your frequent dispathy

lurch

I'm using "believe" in a very narrow sense. I don't believe in the big bang, or evolution like a creationist believes in the Bible. There is no evidence that the universe was created as depicted in the Bible and yet some people believe that it is literally true. 
 
 On the other hand, there are libraries full of evidence for the big bang and evolution. From the science I have studied I recognize that the current theories are the best explanations for the events.
 
 I believe things for which I have no evidence and I accept explanations based on evidence.
 
 You see, I've discussed this stuff enough to know that the minute that I say that I "believe in the big bang theory" that some creationist will claim that it is just a religion like his - he believes in his god and I believe in the big bang.
 
 But I don't see a conflict between science and Christianity. But to be a creationist as you define it it is necessary to actually reject science, not just evolution. I don't see any reason to reject science. It seems that everything around me has natural cause. We have theories about diseases, why it rains, the orbits of the moon and the earth, the movements of the continents, and why populations of organisms change - and on and on. And even if we don't have a clear understanding of the natural causes of some things, why would we give up and say that a supernatural being did it? Creationism answers everything without evidence and therefore answers nothing.
 
 I believe that creationists are idolaters. They have replaced the worship of God with the worship of the Bible. They miss the meaning of Christianity. Christians that I have known who are also scientists look to science as understanding how God created. They don't doubt that he did.

lurch

Is your misrepresentation of what I said intentional?
 
 Let me try again and see if you can catch my drift. When speaking of scientific theories I don't usually say that I "believe" them because too often creationists use that as an excuse to claim that science is a religion. But unlike creationism, which is based on no evidence and, in fact, flies in the face of huge amounts of evidence to the contrary, science isn't just a belief.
 
 You see, I believe what I don't have any evidence of, just as creationists believe that the earth is 6,000 years old.
 
 But there is so much evidence for the big bang, the great age of the universe, the age of the earth, plate tectonics, and the common origin of all life that I don't "believe" it. It is true beyond any reasonable doubt. I see no need to substitute miracle for natural causes.

 That's the thing; it is not the fact man is special. It is part of literalism. Pastor Russell (the "founder") was a person that wandered in and out of various religions even unnamed "oriental" ones. He detested the churches illogical dogmas (like a loving good God making a hell) and liked science. This inertia has always remained. So if JWs are stuck with siding with the church or science and the bible is remotely vague; which happens more then you would think. You know which one we'll pick.
 
 
 Creator chap. 6 pp. 98-99 An Ancient Creation Record-Can You Trust It?
 
 What a climax it was when God assembled some of the elements of the earth to form his first human son, whom he named Adam! (Luke 3:38) The historical account tells us that the Creator of the globe and life on it put the man he had made in a gardenlike area "to cultivate it and to take care of it." (Genesis 2:15) At that time the Creator may still have been producing new animal kinds. The Bible says: "God was forming from the ground every wild beast of the field and every flying creature of the heavens, and he began bringing them to the man to see what he would call each one; and whatever the man would call it, each living soul, that was its name." (Genesis 2:19)
 
 Note it says, "climax... Adam" then says "still have been producing new animal kinds". Obviously must have been a brief climax. Since we don't comment on what we think God actually did, put billions of years before Adam, and then open the other end for more animals after him. This actually fits the fossil record, and what ever else. No scientist can argue other wise. We barely define a "kind", those could be allele in a population (in 15 years the next Creator book replacement will probably go down those lines while still denouncing evolution).  Okay the big bang layman's terms for an open singularity that started the universe and filled it with hydrogen. Since it is a singularity you can't scientifically analyzed or explain it with current theories. Now what can you argue about? The only thing left is change. If the universe was created 6k years ago there is no time for change on a cosmic scale all that hydrogen can't burn into heavier elements. So the big bang can't happen. I know the universe is much older so it does not conflict with anything.
 
 Primeval pool an unknown liquid that can cause chemicals to congeal to living things. It is unknown. That does not conflict with anything. Genesis 1:20 "Let the water teem with living creatures..."
 
 'ape--<man' evolution this does not conflict with Genesis. In science Adam and Eve do not exist as real people. In Genesis man is produced from elements in the ground just like an automobile. The evolution of apes to man is not addressed. I can say Adam did not evolve since he had no biological parents. The homonids are not related to him by heredity (the actual DNA is a different matter). Was there homo sapiens before Adam? I have no idea. Having a soul means nothing to me so it is not like they would be "lower" if they existed.
 
 The debate left is did modern day humans descend from Adam or a prehistoric homo- sapien population? No idea but that would solve the fundy problem of where Cain got his wife from (j/k). The bible talks of sons of God mixing with Adams offspring making hybrids. I have not comment on what that also cloud mean, but a homo-sapien Neanderthal little girl has been found, but it is debated. Neanderthal are also stronger than humansif they are the actual nephlim is unknown. Considering many "smart" homonids went extinct Adams offspring could have caused this for there were supposed to live around the same time. The Genesis gives no comment unless you decide to put words in God's mouth.
